If you are interested in other insights about WFH or want to discuss where work, life, your industry is heading and why, come say Hello@ForesightAlliance.com
All of this to say, as everyone is citing Zoom fatigue as their chief complaint, we encourage you to shut off the camera and just listen.
Also, the coworkers on the video call are not reacting to what you are saying they are concentrating on making sure they are demonstrating attention.

“But, but if it is audio only, you can’t see what people are thinking or how they are reacting?”

True, but that is the same situation you have with phone conferences.
All that attention on the speaker can go to listening and ruminating.
And we don’t have any behavior science to back this up, but we suspect not having to concentrate and DEMONSTRATE your concentration on the speaker allows you to absorb the meeting better.
Audio only means that you can still do that thing that makes F2F meetings bearable: look around, space out, doodle, surreptitiously do other things while the meeting is going on.
As a measure of how old we are, we use Skype, and while Skype allows video, we have always been an audio-only meetings company. Why? For all the reasons you think.
You don’t need to have your cameras on during meetings/calls.
But now, as we look at everyone discussing things they like/hate a year on, we have one piece of best practices that we want to share and should have at the start. Ready?
